skill.name: reading-logseq-data
skill.description: Expert in reading data from Logseq DB graphs via HTTP API or CLI. Auto-invokes when users want to fetch pages, blocks, or properties from Logseq, execute Datalog queries against their graph, search content, or retrieve backlinks and relationships. Provides the logseq-client library for operations.
skill.summary: Expert in reading data from Logseq DB graphs via HTTP API or CLI. Auto-invokes when users want to fe...
skill.author: C0ntr0lledCha0s

security_audit.summary: Read-only data access skill for Logseq knowledge graphs. All 175 static findings are false positives: backticks in markdown are Clojure/Datalog syntax examples, subprocess calls invoke the Logseq CLI with hardcoded arguments, and URLs are localhost endpoints. Environment access is limited to Logseq-specific configuration variables only.

content.user_title: Read Logseq data and execute Datalog queries
content.value_statement: Users need to extract and query data from their Logseq knowledge graphs. This skill provides a unified Python client library for fetching pages, blocks, properties, and executing advanced Datalog queries against local Logseq graphs via HTTP API or CLI.
actual_capabilities: Fetch pages and blocks from Logseq graphs via HTTP API or CLI
Execute Datalog queries against the local Logseq database
Search content across all blocks in a graph
Get page and block properties and metadata
Auto-detect available backends (HTTP API or CLI)
limitations: Write operations are not supported - this is a read-only skill
Requires Logseq to be running with API enabled or CLI installed
Cannot query remote Logseq graphs - only local graphs

use_cases.title: Query personal knowledge base
use_cases.description: Extract and analyze notes, tasks, and references from personal Logseq knowledge graphs for research and planning.

use_cases.title: Build Logseq integrations
use_cases.description: Use the Python client library to read data from Logseq for custom workflows, automation, and reporting.

use_cases.title: Analyze linked references
use_cases.description: Find backlinks, trace relationships, and run complex queries to discover connections across knowledge bases.

prompt_templates.title: Get a page
prompt_templates.prompt: Get the page titled "[Page Title]" from my Logseq graph and show its properties and blocks.

prompt_templates.title: Find by property
prompt_templates.prompt: Find all pages tagged as "[Tag Name]" where the property [Property Name] is greater than [Value].

prompt_templates.title: List backlinks
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me all blocks that reference the page "[Page Title]" and which pages they belong to.

prompt_templates.title: Complex aggregation
prompt_templates.prompt: Count all tasks by status and show which pages have the most incomplete tasks. Use Datalog aggregation.

output_examples.input: Get the page "Meeting Notes" and show all tasks with their status
output: - TODO: Review action items (status: In Progress)

output_examples.input: Find all pages tagged as "Book" with rating greater than 4

best_practices: Use specific pull patterns in Datalog queries to fetch only needed fields instead of wildcard selections
Include filtering clauses early in queries to reduce result sets before processing
Batch multiple item lookups into single queries using the :in clause with list parameters
anti_patterns: Fetching entire graphs with unbounded queries that can cause memory issues
Ignoring error handling for connection failures when Logseq is not running
Running expensive queries during interactive sessions without limit parameters

faq.question: Does this skill require Logseq to be running?
faq.answer: Yes. For HTTP API mode, Logseq must be running with API enabled on localhost port 12315. For CLI mode, the logseq binary must be installed.

faq.question: What types of queries can I run?
faq.answer: This skill supports full Datalog queries including filtering, aggregations, recursive queries, and complex joins across pages and blocks.

faq.question: Can I write data back to Logseq?
faq.answer: No. This skill is read-only. Use the writing-logseq-data skill for write operations like creating pages or updating properties.

faq.question: Is my data sent to external servers?
faq.answer: No. All data stays on your machine. HTTP requests go to localhost (127.0.0.1:12315) and CLI queries access local graph files only.

faq.question: Why does my query return no results?
faq.answer: Check that Logseq is running with API enabled, your graph is loaded, and your query uses correct entity attributes like :block/title.

faq.question: How is this different from direct file access?
faq.answer: This skill uses Logseq official API which understands the graph schema, relationships, and properties that raw files do not expose.
